title: Neurocysticercosis
scope: ** Diagnosis, staging, antiparasitic treatment, corticosteroid management, antiseizure medication selection, and follow-up of neurocysticercosis in adults. Covers all anatomic forms: parenchymal (vesicular, colloidal vesicular, granular nodular, calcified), ventricular (intraventricular), subarachnoid (racemose/basilar), and spinal neurocysticercosis. Includes Del Brutto diagnostic criteria, staging-based treatment approach, albendazole and praziquantel combination therapy, corticosteroid protocols, and surgical indications for hydrocephalus and intraventricular cysts. Excludes ocular cysticercosis (ophthalmology management), isolated subcutaneous cysticercosis without CNS involvement, and pediatric neurocysticercosis (dosing differences).

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Eosinophilia in 10-30% of NCC; baseline for monitoring corticosteroid and antiparasitic toxicity; leukocytosis indicates co-infection or cysticercal encephalitis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Eosinophilia (peripheral) in minority; normal WBC does NOT exclude NCC

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hepatic function for albendazole metabolism (hepatotoxicity risk); renal function baseline; electrolytes for seizure management; glucose monitoring during corticosteroid use
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; monitor LFTs during albendazole course

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Assess inflammatory response to cyst degeneration; elevated during colloidal stage (active inflammation); monitor treatment-related inflammation
Essential/Core Labs.target: Variable; elevated during colloidal vesicular stage; declining with treatment

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Nonspecific inflammatory marker; mildly elevated; useful to distinguish from other infectious etiologies

**Preferred serologic test** — enzyme-linked immunoelectrotransfer blot (EITB) sensitivity 94-98% for >1 viable cyst, specificity ~100%; sensitivity drops to 50-70% for single calcified lesion; positive supports diagnosis per Del Brutto criteria
Essential/Core Labs.target: Positive (reactive to >=1 of 7 glycoprotein antigens); negative does NOT exclude NCC with single lesion or calcified disease

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Screening test; sensitivity 65-87%; specificity 75-100%; less specific than EITB; cross-reacts with other cestodes; use as adjunct if EITB unavailable
Essential/Core Labs.target: Positive supports diagnosis; confirm with EITB if available

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Coagulopathy assessment before LP or surgical intervention
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; correct if abnormal before procedures

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline before corticosteroid therapy; diabetes screening (steroid-induced hyperglycemia common)
Essential/Core Labs.target: HbA1c <6.5%; glucose <180 mg/dL during steroid use

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Albendazole is teratogenic (Category C); praziquantel is Category B; exclude pregnancy before initiating antiparasitic therapy
If sepsis or meningoencephalitis suspected; cysticercal encephalitis with systemic inflammatory response

Extended Workup.item: Serum antigen detection (Ag-ELISA) for T. solium (CPT 86682)
Extended Workup.rationale: Detects circulating parasite antigen; positive indicates viable (living) cysts; useful for monitoring treatment response (declining antigen = cyst death); sensitivity 65-90% for multiple viable cysts
Extended Workup.target: Positive indicates viable cysts; declining titer monitors treatment response; negative in single cyst or calcified disease

Extended Workup.rationale: Immunocompromise assessment; HIV alters NCC presentation and treatment response; concurrent opportunistic infections complicate management
Extended Workup.target: Negative; if positive: obtain CD4 count; affects treatment duration

Extended Workup.rationale: Identify intestinal Taenia solium carriage (taeniasis); present in 5-15% of NCC patients; treatment of intestinal tapeworm prevents ongoing autoinfection and community transmission
Extended Workup.target: Negative; if positive: treat with niclosamide or praziquantel (single dose) for intestinal tapeworm

Extended Workup.rationale: More sensitive than microscopic stool O&P for detecting intestinal Taenia solium; important for public health (household contacts)
Extended Workup.target: Negative; if positive: treat intestinal taeniasis

Extended Workup.rationale: SIADH assessment (intracranial pathology); hyponatremia from cerebral salt wasting; important with corticosteroid use and ICP management
SIADH vs. cerebral salt wasting differentiation; relevant if on mannitol or hypertonic saline for elevated ICP
Screen before high-dose corticosteroids; Strongyloides hyperinfection syndrome is fatal during immunosuppression; endemic area overlap with NCC
Extended Workup.target: Negative required before initiating prolonged corticosteroids; if positive: treat with ivermectin before steroids

Extended Workup.rationale: Albendazole causes hepatotoxicity in 2-5%; monitor during and after treatment; praziquantel primarily hepatically metabolized
Extended Workup.target: Normal; if ALT/AST >3x ULN: hold albendazole

Extended Workup.rationale: If on concurrent AEDs; praziquantel levels reduced by 50-75% with enzyme-inducing AEDs (carbamazepine, phenytoin); albendazole sulfoxide levels reduced by dexamethasone co-administration

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Higher sensitivity than serum for subarachnoid/ventricular NCC; important when serum EITB negative but clinical suspicion high; CSF detects intrathecal antibody production
Rare/Specialized.target: Positive; intrathecal synthesis supports CNS NCC

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Detects viable cysts in CSF; especially useful in subarachnoid (racemose) and ventricular NCC where serum tests less reliable; monitor treatment response
Rare/Specialized.target: Positive indicates viable cysts in CSF space

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Molecular confirmation when serology equivocal; identifies species-specific DNA in CSF; limited availability
**Gold standard** per Del Brutto absolute criteria; identifies scolex, cyst wall, hooklets; confirms T. solium species; from surgical excision or endoscopic removal
Rare/Specialized.target: Parasitic structures: scolex with rostellar hooklets, cyst wall with tegument and subtegumental cells

Rare/Specialized.item: Brain biopsy / cyst excision with pathology
Rare/Specialized.rationale: When diagnosis uncertain despite imaging and serology; to differentiate from tumor, abscess, or other granulomatous disease
Rare/Specialized.target: Cysticercus larva identified; parasitic elements within cyst; surrounding inflammatory tissue

Rare/Specialized.rationale: Tuberculoma is key differential for ring-enhancing lesions in endemic areas with geographic overlap; rule out concurrent TB meningitis
Differential diagnosis in immunocompromised patients; ring-enhancing lesions; especially if HIV-positive
Rare/Specialized.target: Negative; if positive with HIV: evaluate for concurrent toxoplasmosis

Rare/Specialized.rationale: If immunocompromised with atypical enhancement pattern; fungal abscess in differential
Subarachnoid NCC triggers complement-mediated vasculitis; monitor if vasculitis suspected

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated ICP common in ventricular and subarachnoid NCC; hydrocephalus assessment; baseline for monitoring
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal 10-20 cm H2O; elevated in 50% of NCC with active inflammation or hydrocephalus

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: CSF pleocytosis with lymphocytic/eosinophilic predominance; eosinophils (>5%) highly suggestive of parasitic infection; mononuclear predominance in chronic disease
Lumbar Puncture.target: WBC 5-500; **CSF eosinophilia (>5%) strongly supports parasitic etiology**; lymphocytic predominance common; polymorphonuclear in acute cyst rupture

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Elevated in active inflammation and subarachnoid disease; markedly elevated in racemose NCC and arachnoiditis
Lumbar Puncture.target: Mildly to moderately elevated (50-300 mg/dL); markedly elevated (>200) in subarachnoid/racemose NCC

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Low glucose indicates chronic meningitis (subarachnoid NCC, TB meningitis, fungal); usually normal in parenchymal NCC
Lumbar Puncture.target: Normal in parenchymal NCC; low (CSF/serum ratio <0.5) in subarachnoid NCC and chronic cysticercal meningitis

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Higher sensitivity than serum for subarachnoid and ventricular NCC; intrathecal antibody synthesis
Detects viable cysts in CSF; serial monitoring of treatment response in extraparenchymal disease; declining antigen = successful treatment
Lumbar Puncture.target: Positive indicates viable cysts; serial decline with treatment

Lumbar Puncture.rationale: Rule out bacterial meningitis as concurrent or alternative diagnosis
Rule out TB meningitis (key differential in endemic areas with overlapping epidemiology)
Rule out fungal meningitis (Coccidioides, Histoplasma, Cryptococcus) if immunocompromised or endemic area
Rule out leptomeningeal carcinomatosis if atypical presentation or subarachnoid enhancement

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate; first-line in ED for seizure, headache; **best for detecting calcified lesions** which MRI misses
Essential/First-line.target: **Calcified granulomas** (most common finding in endemic areas); single or multiple calcified nodules; perilesional edema around calcified lesion (seizure trigger); hydrocephalus; parenchymal cysts
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Pregnancy (relative; benefit outweighs risk in acute setting)

Essential/First-line.timing: Immediate if non-contrast shows edema or cysts; **ring enhancement identifies colloidal/granular stage**
Essential/First-line.target: Ring-enhancing lesion (colloidal vesicular stage); disc enhancement (granular nodular stage); calcified nodules with or without surrounding edema; **scolex** visible as eccentric hyperdense dot within cyst

Essential/First-line.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Essential/First-line.timing: Within 24h if CT suspicious; **gold standard** for NCC staging, cyst counting, scolex visualization, and identifying ventricular/subarachnoid disease
Essential/First-line.target: **Vesicular stage:** CSF-intensity cyst with scolex (bright dot on FLAIR); **Colloidal stage:** ring enhancement, perilesional edema, bright cyst fluid on FLAIR; **Granular nodular:** nodular/ring enhancement, decreasing edema; **Calcified:** T2 hypointense, perilesional edema possible; **Ventricular:** mobile cyst within ventricle; **Subarachnoid/racemose:** multilobulated grape-like cysts in cisterns
Soft tissue calcifications (subcutaneous/muscular cysticerci, "cigar-shaped" calcifications); pulmonary findings; baseline

Extended.item: MRI spine with and without contrast (CPT 72156)
Extended.target: Intradural extramedullary or intramedullary cysticercus; spinal leptomeningeal enhancement; arachnoiditis; subarachnoid cysts along spinal cord

Extended.timing: If subarachnoid NCC suspected but standard imaging equivocal; enhances visualization of cisternal cysts
Extended.target: Racemose cysts in basal cisterns; filling defects in subarachnoid space

Extended.item: Plain radiographs of thighs and shoulders (CPT 73552+73030)
Extended.timing: Screening for disseminated cysticercosis; confirm systemic disease
Extended.target: **Cigar-shaped calcifications** in muscles (pathognomonic for disseminated cysticercosis); supports NCC diagnosis per Del Brutto minor criteria

Extended.timing: If seizure at presentation; baseline for patients starting AED therapy; evaluate for subclinical seizure activity
Extended.target: Focal epileptiform discharges corresponding to cyst location; generalized abnormalities; background slowing

Extended.timing: If altered mental status; concern for cysticercal encephalitis with non-convulsive seizures; refractory seizures
If cardiac cysticercosis suspected (rare); disseminated disease
If visual symptoms or concern for ocular cysticercosis; **rule out ocular cysts before starting antiparasitic therapy** (treatment causes cyst inflammation that destroys vision)
Extended.target: Intraocular or periorbital cysticercus; retinal cyst; subretinal cyst

Extended.timing: **MANDATORY before starting antiparasitic treatment**; ocular cysticercosis is a contraindication to antiparasitic drugs; treatment-induced inflammation causes blindness
Extended.target: Intraocular cyst (vitreous, retinal, subretinal); papilledema (elevated ICP)

Extended.timing: Baseline; QTc assessment before medications; cardiac cysticercosis screen in disseminated disease
Extended.target: Normal; QTc prolongation risk with some AEDs

Rare/Specialized.timing: For intraventricular cyst visualization; superior to standard MRI for small ventricular and subarachnoid cysts
Rare/Specialized.target: Intraventricular cyst outline clearly delineated; scolex visible; cyst relationship to ventricular walls and foramina

Rare/Specialized.timing: If mobile intraventricular cyst suspected (ball-valve hydrocephalus); demonstrates cyst mobility with CSF flow
Rare/Specialized.target: Mobile cyst causing intermittent foramen obstruction

Rare/Specialized.timing: If diagnosis uncertain despite standard workup; differentiate from neoplasm
Rare/Specialized.target: Cysticercal lesion: minimal FDG uptake (peripheral inflammatory ring); neoplasm: diffuse uptake

Rare/Specialized.timing: Acute hydrocephalus from ventricular cyst obstruction; declining consciousness from cysticercal encephalitis
Intraventricular cyst removal; direct visualization and excision; avoids open craniotomy
Rare/Specialized.target: Cyst visualized and excised intact; scolex identified; cyst-free ventricle post-procedure

Acute/Emergent.indication: Pre-treatment corticosteroid BEFORE antiparasitic therapy; reduces treatment-induced inflammation from cyst degeneration; essential for cysticercal encephalitis; subarachnoid NCC with arachnoiditis

dosing.instructions: 0.15 mg/kg IV q6h (typically 4-8 mg q6h); start 1-2 days BEFORE antiparasitic drugs; taper over 2-4 weeks based on clinical response; longer courses for subarachnoid NCC; dexamethasone increases albendazole sulfoxide levels by 50%

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Active untreated fungal/bacterial infection; uncontrolled diabetes (relative); GI bleed (relative)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q6h during IV therapy; GI prophylaxis; blood pressure; mood changes; taper schedule; infection signs

Acute/Emergent.indication: First-line antiseizure medication for NCC-related seizures; no hepatic enzyme induction (avoids reducing praziquantel levels); seizures occur in 70-90% of parenchymal NCC

dosing.instructions: 1000 mg IV load, then 500-1000 mg IV/PO BID; titrate by 500 mg/day every 2 weeks to 1500 mg BID if seizures persist; max 3000 mg/day; does NOT interact with antiparasitic drugs

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Severe renal impairment (dose adjust CrCl <30); behavioral side effects
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Renal function; behavioral/mood changes (irritability, depression); CBC

Acute/Emergent.indication: Elevated ICP from cysticercal encephalitis, large perilesional edema, or obstructive hydrocephalus; bridge to definitive treatment

dosing.instructions: 1-1.5 g/kg IV bolus over 20 min; then 0.25-0.5 g/kg q4-6h PRN for ICP >22; hold if serum osm >320

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Anuria; severe dehydration; active intracranial bleeding
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Serum osmolality (<320 mOsm/kg); osmolar gap; renal function; serum Na; I/O

Acute/Emergent.indication: Acute herniation from massive cerebral edema in cysticercal encephalitis; more sustained ICP reduction than mannitol

dosing.instructions: 30 mL via central line over 10-20 min; target Na 145-155 mEq/L; repeat PRN

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: No central access (causes tissue necrosis peripherally)
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Serum Na q4-6h; osmolality; central line access confirmed

Acute/Emergent.indication: Active seizure in NCC; breakthrough seizure during antiparasitic treatment

dosing.instructions: 0.1 mg/kg IV (max 4 mg) over 2 min; repeat x1 in 5 min if seizure continues; max 8 mg total

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Respiratory rate; SpO2; blood pressure; airway equipment at bedside

Acute/Emergent.indication: Maintenance fluids; avoid hypotonic solutions which worsen cerebral edema; euvolemia during corticosteroid therapy

dosing.instructions: Isotonic fluids only; avoid D5W and half-normal saline; maintain euvolemia

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Headache management; fever control; avoid NSAIDs if concern for GI bleed during corticosteroid therapy

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4 g/day; IV route if unable to take PO

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic disease (caution with concurrent albendazole hepatotoxicity)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Nausea and vomiting (common with elevated ICP and antiparasitic therapy; albendazole commonly causes nausea)

dosing.instructions: 4 mg IV/PO q6h PRN nausea; max 16 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: QT prolongation; severe hepatic impairment (max 8 mg/day)
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: QTc if risk factors; hepatic function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: GI prophylaxis during corticosteroid therapy; stress ulcer prevention in ICU; steroid-induced gastropathy prevention

dosing.instructions: 40 mg IV/PO daily; discontinue when steroids stopped and no longer in ICU

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Long-term use risks (C. diff, hypomagnesemia); only while on steroids
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: GI symptoms; discontinue when steroids tapered

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: DVT prophylaxis; prolonged hospitalization and immobilization; steroid use increases VTE risk

dosing.instructions: 40 mg SC daily; start 24h post-surgery if no active bleeding; hold if upcoming surgery

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Active intracranial bleeding; recent craniotomy (<24h); coagulopathy; platelets <50K
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Platelets q3 days (HIT monitoring); coagulation panel

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: DVT prophylaxis; apply on admission; use in conjunction with pharmacologic prophylaxis when safe

dosing.instructions: Bilateral sequential compression devices; apply on admission; continue until fully ambulatory

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Acute DVT in lower extremity; severe peripheral vascular disease

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Refractory seizure not responding to levetiracetam; status epilepticus; **NOTE: phenytoin/fosphenytoin is enzyme-inducing and reduces praziquantel levels by 50%**

doseOptions.orderSentence: Fosphenytoin (seizure rescue second-line) 20 mg PE/kg IV

dosing.instructions: 20 mg PE/kg IV at 150 mg PE/min; maintenance 100 mg PE q8h; target free phenytoin level 1-2 mcg/mL
dosing.orderSentence: Fosphenytoin (seizure rescue second-line) 20 mg PE/kg IV

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Bradycardia; second/third-degree heart block; hypotension; reduces praziquantel levels
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Continuous telemetry during load; free phenytoin level; LFTs; drug interactions with antiparasitic agents

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Second-line AED for NCC-related seizures; no enzyme induction (preferred over carbamazepine/phenytoin which reduce praziquantel levels)

dosing.instructions: 200 mg IV load, then 100-200 mg PO BID; max 400 mg/day; no significant drug interactions with antiparasitic agents

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: PR prolongation; second/third-degree AV block; severe hepatic impairment

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.indication: **First-line antiparasitic** for viable parenchymal NCC (vesicular and colloidal stages); 1-2 viable cysts: albendazole monotherapy x 7-14 days; >2 viable cysts: combine with praziquantel; subarachnoid/racemose NCC: prolonged courses (months); take with fatty meal (increases absorption 5-fold)

dosing.instructions: 15 mg/kg/day PO divided BID (standard max 400 mg BID = 800 mg/day; up to 600 mg BID = 1200 mg/day for subarachnoid NCC or heavy cyst burden per ID specialist guidance); take with fatty meal; duration: 7-14 days for 1-2 parenchymal cysts; 10-14 days for >2 cysts (with praziquantel); weeks to months for subarachnoid NCC

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.contraindications: **Ocular cysticercosis** (ABSOLUTE — causes vision loss); pregnancy (teratogenic); severe hepatic disease; cysticercal encephalitis with uncontrolled edema (treat edema first)
Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.monitoring: LFTs at baseline, day 7, day 14, then biweekly; CBC q2 weeks (leukopenia, thrombocytopenia); clinical response; repeat imaging at 3-6 months

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.indication: **Combined with albendazole** for >2 viable parenchymal cysts (combination more effective than either alone per RCTs); single agent if albendazole intolerance; **NOTE: levels reduced 50-75% by enzyme-inducing AEDs (carbamazepine, phenytoin) and by dexamethasone — increase dose or use cimetidine to boost levels**

dosing.instructions: 50 mg/kg/day PO divided TID; take with fatty meal; combine with albendazole for >2 viable cysts; duration 10-14 days for parenchymal NCC; if on enzyme-inducing AEDs: increase dose to 100 mg/kg/day or add cimetidine 400 mg TID to inhibit metabolism

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.contraindications: **Ocular cysticercosis** (ABSOLUTE); pregnancy (Category B but avoid during treatment); concurrent rifampin (reduces levels markedly); cysticercal encephalitis with uncontrolled edema
Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.monitoring: LFTs; clinical response; drug interactions (enzyme-inducing AEDs reduce levels by 50-75%); repeat imaging at 3-6 months

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.indication: Inhibits CYP3A4 metabolism of praziquantel; increases praziquantel bioavailability 2-fold; essential when enzyme-inducing AEDs cannot be avoided

dosing.instructions: 400 mg PO TID; start 1-2 days before praziquantel; continue throughout praziquantel course

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.contraindications: Renal impairment (dose adjust); drug interactions (inhibits CYP3A4)

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.indication: Transition from IV dexamethasone; prolonged steroid course for subarachnoid NCC; maintenance anti-inflammatory therapy during outpatient antiparasitic treatment

dosing.instructions: 1 mg/kg/day PO (max 60 mg) then taper over 2-4 weeks for parenchymal NCC; for subarachnoid/racemose NCC: prolonged taper over months (years for chronic arachnoiditis)

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.contraindications: Active infections; uncontrolled diabetes; GI ulcer; osteoporosis (relative for prolonged use)
Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.monitoring: Glucose; blood pressure; weight; bone density if prolonged use (>3 months); mood changes; infection signs; adrenal suppression

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.indication: Steroid-sparing agent for subarachnoid/racemose NCC requiring prolonged anti-inflammatory therapy (months to years); allows corticosteroid taper while maintaining anti-inflammatory effect

dosing.instructions: Start 7.5 mg PO weekly; titrate to 15-20 mg weekly as tolerated; supplement with folic acid 1 mg daily (except on MTX day); onset of effect 4-6 weeks

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.contraindications: Pregnancy (teratogenic); severe hepatic/renal impairment; immunodeficiency; bone marrow suppression; interstitial lung disease
Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.monitoring: CBC with differential monthly; LFTs monthly; renal function monthly; folic acid compliance; pulmonary symptoms

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.indication: Treatment of intestinal Taenia solium (taeniasis) to eliminate tapeworm and prevent ongoing autoinfection and community transmission

dosing.instructions: 2 g PO as single dose (chew thoroughly then swallow with water); take on empty stomach; purge 2h after to expel worm segments

Second-line/Refractory — Antiparasitic T.monitoring: Stool follow-up at 1 and 3 months post-treatment to confirm eradication; household contacts screened

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: **Preferred approach** for intraventricular cysticercosis; direct visualization and excision of cyst; avoids open craniotomy; lateral and third ventricle cysts most amenable; fourth ventricle more challenging

dosing.instructions: Single procedure; cyst removed intact when possible; combined with ventriculostomy if hydrocephalus
dosing.orderSentence: Neuroendoscopic cyst removal - Surgical - see dosing

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).pretreatment: MRI with FIESTA/CISS sequences to localize cyst; coagulation panel (INR <1.5, platelets >100K); neurosurgery consultation; anesthesia clearance
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).contraindications: Coagulopathy (correct first); inaccessible cyst location; severe inflammation precluding safe dissection
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: Post-procedure MRI within 24-48h; neurologic exam q1h x 6h then q2h; signs of hemorrhage; CSF leak; hydrocephalus resolution

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: Obstructive hydrocephalus from subarachnoid (racemose) NCC or chronic arachnoiditis; communicating hydrocephalus from chronic meningitis; when endoscopic cyst removal not feasible or hydrocephalus persists after cyst removal

dosing.instructions: Permanent CSF diversion; programmable valve preferred
dosing.orderSentence: VP shunt placement - Surgical - see dosing

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).pretreatment: CT/MRI confirming hydrocephalus; coagulation panel; neurosurgery consultation; assess for shunt infection risk
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).contraindications: Active CNS infection (relative; requires simultaneous treatment); coagulopathy
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: Shunt function (clinical and imaging); shunt infection surveillance; ventricular size on follow-up imaging; signs of over-drainage or under-drainage

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: Alternative to VP shunt for obstructive hydrocephalus; avoids shunt dependency; combine with endoscopic cyst removal when feasible

dosing.instructions: Single procedure; creates CSF pathway bypassing obstruction
dosing.orderSentence: Endoscopic third ventriculostomy (ETV) - Surgical - see dosing

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).pretreatment: MRI anatomy assessment; coagulation panel; neurosurgery
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).contraindications: Communicating hydrocephalus (ETV less effective); basilar artery adherent to floor of third ventricle
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: Post-procedure imaging; neurologic exam; ICP monitoring if EVD placed

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: Large parenchymal cyst with significant mass effect not amenable to medical therapy; giant subarachnoid (racemose) cyst; fourth ventricle cyst not amenable to endoscopic removal; diagnostic uncertainty requiring tissue

dosing.instructions: Complete excision of cyst with capsule when feasible
dosing.orderSentence: Craniotomy with cyst excision - Surgical - see dosing

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).pretreatment: CT/MRI navigation imaging; coagulation panel; type and crossmatch; corticosteroid pre-treatment; neurosurgery and anesthesia
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).contraindications: Multiple deep cysts; eloquent cortex (relative); severe comorbidities precluding general anesthesia
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: Post-operative neurologic exam q1h x 12h then q2h; CT at 24h; wound care; ICP if EVD; seizure monitoring

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).indication: Acute obstructive hydrocephalus from ventricular cyst; cysticercal encephalitis with elevated ICP; bridge to definitive treatment

dosing.instructions: Continuous or intermittent CSF drainage; target ICP <22 mmHg; target CPP >60 mmHg
dosing.orderSentence: External ventricular drain (EVD) - Surgical - see dosing

Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).pretreatment: Coagulation panel; neurosurgery; CT confirming hydrocephalus
Surgical Management (Disease-Modifying).monitoring: ICP continuous; CSF output hourly; CSF culture daily; EVD site care; neurologic exam q1h

Referrals & Consults.item: Infectious disease consultation for antiparasitic regimen selection, dosing optimization, drug interactions, and treatment duration guidance
Neurosurgery consultation for ventricular cysts, hydrocephalus management (VP shunt, ETV, EVD), large cysts with mass effect, and diagnostic tissue sampling
Neurology consultation for seizure management, AED selection (avoiding enzyme-inducing agents), EEG interpretation, and long-term epilepsy management
Ophthalmology consultation MANDATORY before initiating antiparasitic therapy to rule out ocular cysticercosis (treatment-induced inflammation causes blindness)
Critical care/ICU team for cysticercal encephalitis with diffuse cerebral edema, elevated ICP, herniation, or respiratory failure
Gastroenterology consultation if intestinal taeniasis confirmed for treatment and surveillance
Endocrinology consultation for corticosteroid-induced diabetes management during prolonged steroid courses (especially subarachnoid NCC requiring months of therapy)
Public health notification and household contact screening for Taenia solium (stool examination of household members; identify tapeworm carrier to prevent ongoing transmission)
Pharmacy consultation for drug interaction management (praziquantel interactions with enzyme-inducing AEDs; albendazole bioavailability optimization; cimetidine boosting)
Physical therapy for deconditioning prevention and rehabilitation if focal deficits present
Social work for discharge planning, medication access (albendazole availability), immigration/insurance barriers common in endemic populations
Neuropsychology referral if cognitive complaints persist after treatment (encephalitis, multiple cysts, or chronic hydrocephalus cause lasting cognitive impact)

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if worsening headache, new confusion, seizure, fever, new weakness, vision changes, or vomiting (indicates treatment-induced inflammation, hydrocephalus, or cysticercal encephalitis)
Take albendazole WITH a fatty meal (increases drug absorption 5-fold; without fat, most of the drug is not absorbed and treatment fails)
Do NOT stop corticosteroids abruptly (adrenal crisis risk with sudden discontinuation; taper as directed by physician; risk increases after >2 weeks of use)
Report any yellowing of skin/eyes, dark urine, or right upper abdominal pain (signs of albendazole hepatotoxicity requiring medication hold and evaluation)
Take antiseizure medications as prescribed; do NOT stop abruptly (risk of breakthrough seizure; NCC is the leading cause of adult-onset epilepsy worldwide)
Do NOT drive until cleared by neurology due to seizure risk (state laws typically require 3-12 months seizure-free; NCC-related seizures recur even after cyst resolution)
Follow-up MRI scans are essential to confirm cyst resolution (typically at 3 and 6 months after treatment; some cysts take 12+ months to fully resolve or calcify)
Report any vision changes immediately (indicates ocular cysticercosis or treatment-related intraocular inflammation)
Ensure household members are screened for intestinal Taenia solium by stool examination (identifying and treating the tapeworm carrier prevents ongoing transmission)
Practice strict hand hygiene and food safety: wash hands thoroughly before eating and after using the restroom; wash all fruits and vegetables; cook pork to internal temperature of >=145F (63C)
Bring all medications to every follow-up visit for medication reconciliation and compliance assessment
Follow-up with neurology in 4-6 weeks for seizure assessment, AED level monitoring, and imaging review
Follow-up with infectious disease in 2-4 weeks for antiparasitic treatment response assessment and lab monitoring

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Food safety education: thoroughly cook all pork products to internal temperature >=145F (63C); avoid raw or undercooked pork (prevents intestinal tapeworm acquisition)
Hand hygiene education: wash hands with soap and water before preparing food, before eating, and after using the restroom (fecal-oral transmission of T. solium eggs causes cysticercosis)
Water safety: drink boiled or filtered water in endemic areas; avoid consuming water potentially contaminated with human feces
Seizure safety precautions: avoid heights, swimming alone, unsupervised bathing, and operating heavy machinery until seizure-free period established per neurology guidance
Glycemic control optimization during corticosteroid therapy (monitor glucose closely; initiate insulin or oral hypoglycemic agents during treatment as needed)
Bone health: calcium 1000-1200 mg/day and vitamin D 1000-2000 IU/day supplementation during prolonged corticosteroid use (>3 months); DEXA scan if prolonged steroid course anticipated
Screen household contacts for T. solium tapeworm carriage with stool O&P and/or coproantigen testing (public health imperative to interrupt transmission cycle)
Travel counseling for patients returning to endemic areas: emphasize food and water hygiene, pork cooking practices, and sanitation
Avoid alcohol during antiparasitic therapy (hepatotoxicity risk with albendazole potentiated by alcohol; impairs medication compliance)
Stress management and mental health support (chronic disease management; immigration-related stressors common in endemic populations; seizure-related anxiety and depression)
Gradual return to work and daily activities with seizure precautions; driving restrictions per state law; employer notification if safety-sensitive occupation
Women of childbearing age: effective contraception MANDATORY during albendazole therapy and for 1 month after completion (albendazole is teratogenic)
Follow-up imaging schedule: MRI at 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, then annually until cyst resolution confirmed and seizure-free; longer follow-up for subarachnoid NCC

differential.features: Endemic area overlap; ring-enhancing or solid nodular lesion; conglomerate lesions; basilar meningeal enhancement; no scolex; slower progression; constitutional symptoms
differential.tests: QuantiFERON-TB Gold; chest imaging; AFB culture; CSF TB PCR; biopsy with caseating granulomas; response to anti-TB therapy; NO scolex on imaging

differential.features: Ring-enhancing lesion with DWI restriction; fever; acute presentation; peripheral leukocytosis; thinner wall on ventricular side; no scolex
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion = abscess; NCC does NOT restrict); blood cultures; fever pattern; surgical aspiration with Gram stain and culture

differential.features: Multiple ring-enhancing lesions at gray-white junction; known primary malignancy; progressive neurologic decline; no scolex; surrounded by vasogenic edema
differential.tests: CT chest/abdomen/pelvis for primary; no DWI restriction; no scolex; no calcifications; biopsy if uncertain

differential.features: Irregular thick ring enhancement; necrotic center without scolex; older age; progressive over weeks; mass effect disproportionate to size
differential.tests: MRI DWI (no restriction); MR spectroscopy (elevated choline); PET (hypermetabolic); biopsy

differential.features: HIV/AIDS with CD4 <100; multiple ring-enhancing lesions in basal ganglia; no scolex; responds to empiric therapy within 2 weeks
differential.tests: Toxoplasma IgG (>95% positive); CD4 count; empiric treatment trial; no calcifications; serology

differential.features: Periventricular homogeneous enhancement; immunocompromised or immunocompetent; no scolex; responds dramatically to steroids (ghost tumor)
differential.tests: MRI (homogeneous enhancement); CSF cytology; EBV PCR in CSF; avoid steroids before biopsy; no calcifications

differential.features: Extra-axial dural-based mass; homogeneous enhancement with dural tail; no scolex; no calcification pattern of NCC
differential.tests: MRI (extra-axial, dural-based, dural tail); no DWI restriction; no ring enhancement; biopsy if uncertain

differential.features: Anterior third ventricle location; hyperdense on CT; no enhancement; intermittent hydrocephalus; positional headache
differential.tests: CT (hyperdense third ventricle cyst); MRI (variable signal but no scolex); no enhancement; no serologic markers

differential.features: CSF-intensity cyst WITHOUT scolex; no enhancement; no perilesional edema; no calcification; congenital; asymptomatic or mass effect
differential.tests: MRI (CSF signal on ALL sequences, no scolex, no enhancement, no FLAIR signal); negative serology; stable on serial imaging

differential.features: CSF-like cyst on T1/T2 but RESTRICTS on DWI (unlike arachnoid cyst); pearly white appearance; extra-axial; no scolex
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion unlike NCC cyst); no enhancement; no scolex; no calcification; no serology

differential.features: Popcorn-like lesion with hemosiderin rim; mixed signal on MRI; no enhancement (typically); seizures; no scolex; blooming on GRE/SWI
differential.tests: MRI GRE/SWI (prominent hemosiderin blooming); no enhancement; no scolex; gradient echo sequences diagnostic; negative serology

differential.features: Calcification on CT; mimics calcified NCC; vascular flow voids on MRI; history of hemorrhage or incidental finding
differential.tests: CTA/MRA (vascular malformation); angiography (definitive); no scolex; negative serology; different calcification pattern

evidence.recommendation: Del Brutto diagnostic criteria for NCC
evidence.source: [Del Brutto et al. J Neurol Sci 2017](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28320184/) — revised diagnostic criteria with absolute, major, minor, and epidemiologic criteria
[Garcia et al. N Engl J Med 2004](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15306668/) — randomized controlled trial demonstrating albendazole reduces seizure burden and promotes cyst resolution

evidence.recommendation: Combination albendazole + praziquantel for >2 viable cysts
evidence.source: [Garcia et al. Lancet Infect Dis 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25444472/) — RCT showing combination therapy superior to albendazole alone for multiple cysts

evidence.recommendation: Corticosteroids before and during antiparasitic therapy
evidence.source: [Garcia et al. N Engl J Med 2004](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/15306668/); [IDSA/ASTMH Guidelines — White et al. Clin Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29481580/)

evidence.recommendation: IDSA/ASTMH Clinical Practice Guidelines for NCC
evidence.source: [White et al. Clin Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29481580/) — comprehensive guidelines for diagnosis and treatment of NCC

evidence.recommendation: No antiparasitic therapy for calcified NCC
evidence.source: [White et al. Clin Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29481580/) — calcified lesions are dead parasites; antiparasitic therapy has no target; AEDs for seizures
[Tsang et al. J Infect Dis 1989](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2715568/) — EITB sensitivity 94-98% for >1 viable cyst; specificity ~100%

evidence.recommendation: Enzyme-inducing AEDs reduce praziquantel levels by 50-75%
evidence.source: [Bittencourt et al. Neurology 1992](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1549209/) — phenytoin and carbamazepine significantly reduce praziquantel bioavailability; prefer non-enzyme-inducing AEDs

evidence.recommendation: Ophthalmologic exam mandatory before antiparasitic therapy
evidence.source: [White et al. Clin Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29481580/) — treatment-induced inflammation causes vision loss in ocular NCC; absolute contraindication

evidence.recommendation: Neuroendoscopy preferred for intraventricular cyst removal
evidence.source: [Sinha & Sharma. Neurosurg Focus 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22537130/) — endoscopic approach offers direct visualization with lower morbidity than open surgery for ventricular cysts

evidence.recommendation: VP shunt for chronic hydrocephalus in subarachnoid NCC
evidence.source: [White et al. Clin Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29481580/) — chronic arachnoiditis causes communicating hydrocephalus requiring permanent CSF diversion

evidence.recommendation: Prolonged antiparasitic therapy for subarachnoid NCC
evidence.source: [Proano et al. Ann Intern Med 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11293476/) — subarachnoid (racemose) NCC requires prolonged courses (months); monitor with CSF antigen

evidence.recommendation: NCC is the leading cause of adult-onset epilepsy worldwide
evidence.source: [Ndimubanzi et al. PLoS Negl Trop Dis 2010](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21152057/) — systematic review confirming NCC accounts for ~30% of epilepsy in endemic areas

evidence.recommendation: Methotrexate as steroid-sparing agent for subarachnoid NCC
evidence.source: [Mitre et al. Clin Infect Dis 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/17712753/) — case series supporting methotrexate for chronic arachnoiditis requiring prolonged immunosuppression

evidence.recommendation: Albendazole bioavailability increased 5-fold with fatty meal
evidence.source: [Mottier et al. J Pharm Pharmacol 2006](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/16553415/) — pharmacokinetic studies demonstrating critical importance of fatty meal for drug absorption

[White et al. Clin Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29481580/) — antiparasitic drugs worsen cerebral edema in cysticercal encephalitis; control edema first with corticosteroids and ICP management

evidence.recommendation: Dexamethasone increases albendazole sulfoxide levels by 50%
evidence.source: [Jung et al. J Clin Pharmacol 1990](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/2229455/) — pharmacokinetic synergy; concurrent dexamethasone enhances albendazole efficacy

evidence.recommendation: Serial MRI for monitoring treatment response
evidence.source: Expert consensus; [White et al. Clin Infect Dis 2018](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29481580/) — imaging at 3 and 6 months; cyst resolution or calcification confirms successful treatment

monitoring.action: If declining: STAT CT; assess for treatment-induced inflammation, hydrocephalus; hold antiparasitic if worsening; increase corticosteroids
If persistent high fever: evaluate for bacterial superinfection; cysticercal encephalitis; other etiology

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; day 7; day 14 of albendazole; then biweekly during treatment
monitoring.action: If ALT/AST >3x ULN: HOLD albendazole; recheck in 1 week; resume at lower dose if normalized or switch to praziquantel monotherapy

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; weekly during antiparasitic therapy; q2 weeks during prolonged courses
monitoring.action: If leukopenia or thrombocytopenia: hold albendazole; recheck in 1 week; dose reduction

monitoring.frequency: q6h during IV dexamethasone; daily during oral steroid taper; each OPD visit
monitoring.action: If persistently elevated: start insulin sliding scale or oral hypoglycemic; endocrine consultation for prolonged steroid courses

monitoring.frequency: Daily x 3 then twice weekly inpatient; each OPD visit during steroid taper
monitoring.action: If <130: SIADH workup; fluid restriction; if <120: 3% saline

monitoring.frequency: Once at steady state; after dose changes; if breakthrough seizures
monitoring.action: Adjust dosing; assess compliance; drug interaction review

monitoring.frequency: At 3 months, 6 months, 12 months post-treatment; then annually until resolved
monitoring.action: If enlarging or new cysts: retreat with antiparasitic; if new edema around calcification: short steroid course; neurosurgery if hydrocephalus

monitoring.frequency: Clinical: continuous inpatient; EEG if altered consciousness; OPD: seizure diary
monitoring.action: If seizures: optimize AED levels; add second agent; continuous EEG in ICU; assess for new cyst inflammation

monitoring.frequency: Baseline; at 3 months; at 6 months; then q6 months until negative
monitoring.action: If rising or stable: treatment failure; extend antiparasitic course; reassess surgical options
Tiered ICP management: CSF drainage, osmotherapy, sedation, surgical decompression

monitoring.frequency: Baseline before treatment; at 3 months; if new visual symptoms
monitoring.action: If new intraocular findings: HOLD antiparasitic; urgent ophthalmology

disposition.criteria: Clinically stable; seizure-free >=48h on AEDs; tolerating oral medications (antiparasitic + steroids + AED); no signs of elevated ICP; no hydrocephalus on imaging; outpatient MRI and lab follow-up arranged; neurology and ID follow-up confirmed within 2-4 weeks; reliable medication access and compliance anticipated

New NCC diagnosis with active parenchymal cysts requiring initiation of antiparasitic therapy under observation; mild headache without signs of elevated ICP; GCS >=14; seizures controlled on medication; monitoring for treatment-induced inflammation during first 48-72h of antiparasitic + steroid initiation

Cysticercal encephalitis (massive edema, diffuse viable cysts); acute hydrocephalus requiring EVD; GCS <13 or declining; herniation syndrome; refractory seizures or status epilepticus; post-operative monitoring after craniotomy or endoscopic cyst removal; need for ICP monitoring

Need for neurosurgery not available at current facility (endoscopic cyst removal, VP shunt, craniotomy); need for neuro-ICU expertise; need for continuous EEG not available; need for specialized NCC serologic testing
